title: Asymptotics for Multiple Q-Orthogonal Polynomials from the RHP.pdf
abstract: . We deduce the asymptotic behaviour of a broad class of multiple q-orthogonal polynomials as their degree tends to inﬁnity. We achieve this by rephrasing multiple q-orthogonal polynomials as part of a solution to a Riemann Hilbert Problem (RHP). In particular, we study multiple q-orthogonal polynomials of the ﬁrst kind (see [12]), which are Type II orthogonal polynomials with weights given by w1(x) = xαω(x)dqx, w2(x) = xβω(x)dqx, which satisfy the constraint |ω(q2n) −1| = O(q2n), as n →∞. Using q-calculus we obtain detailed asymptotics for these polynomials from the RHP. This class of polyno- mials studied was chosen in part due to their connection to the work of [11, 12], concerning the irrationality of ζq(1) and ζq(2). To conduct our asymptotic analysis we will require the following added restrictions on w1(x) and w2(x): α /∈Z, β /∈Z and α ̸= β mod Z. These restrictions are necessary for the asymptotic analysis but not the statement of multiple q-orthogonal polynomials as solutions to a RHP. First, we wish to investigate how the theory presented in [7], for q-orthogonal polynomials with a single orthogonality condition, extends to multiple q-orthogonal polynomials. In [7] we were able to determined the strong asymptotics for q-orthogonal polynomials using the RHP and q-calculus. As far as we know, these results are the most accurate description of the asymptotics of q-orthogonal polynomials found in the literature. Interestingly, in [7] we observed that if polynomials P (1) n (x) and P (2) n (x) were such that their weights satisﬁed lim x→0 w(1)(x) w(2)(x) = 1, then P (1) n (x) and P (2) n (x) had the same asymptotic behaviour (to second order) as n →∞(there are some additional minor details to consider for which the reader can refer to [7]).
